The oncology team notes that the tumor appears to be located in the thalamus on a repeat scan, but the radiology report still describes a pontine lesion. No information is provided regarding prior treatments, performance status, or the child's genetic background. The family asks about the prognosis and whether enrollment in a clinical trial targeting the BRAF V600E mutation is appropriate.

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old girl presented with a 3‑month history of progressive gait instability, dysphagia, and new onset of diplopia. MRI of the brain showed a diffuse, infiltrative lesion centered in the pons, measuring 3.2 cm in greatest dimension, with characteristic T2 hyperintensity and mild contrast enhancement. She underwent a stereotactic biopsy, and molecular profiling revealed an H3‑K27M mutation (histone H3.3) and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V mutation; no BRAF V600E mutation was detected. Baseline laboratory studies were within normal limits except for a hemoglobin of 12.1 g/dL and platelet count of 210 ×10⁹/L. Her performance status was Karnofsky 80.

The patient received standard focal radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions over 6 weeks) without concurrent chemotherapy. Four weeks after completing radiation, she was enrolled in a phase II clinical trial evaluating the combination of panobinostat and ONC201. Panobinostat was administered orally at 20 mg/m² three times weekly (Monday, Wednesday, Friday), and ONC201 was given orally at 625 mg once weekly. She tolerated the regimen well, with the only notable adverse event being Grade 2 thrombocytopenia (platelet nadir 85 ×10⁹/L) that resolved without dose modification. Serial MRIs at 8‑ and 12‑week intervals demonstrated stable disease.

At the 4‑month assessment (approximately 16 weeks after trial initiation), repeat MRI revealed new, focal enhancing nodules within the pons and extension into the bilateral middle cerebellar peduncles, consistent with disease progression. The treating team discontinued the investigational regimen. Given the lack of FDA‑approved targeted therapies for H3‑K27M‑mutant diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, the oncologist reviewed available options. Temozolomide is FDA‑approved for adult high‑grade glioma but has limited efficacy in pediatric DIPG and was previously considered unsuitable due to the patient’s prior radiation and modest hematologic reserve. A separate phase I/II trial investigating the EZH2 inhibitor tazemetostat (800 mg/m² twice daily) in H3‑K27M‑mutant pediatric gliomas is currently recruiting and permits enrollment of patients who have progressed after radiation and a prior investigational agent. No other active trials targeting ACVR1 mutations were available in the region.

The family wishes to pursue the most evidence‑based, mutation‑directed therapy while minimizing further hematologic toxicity.
ground_truth.question: Considering the patient’s H3‑K27M mutation, prior exposure to panobinostat + ONC201, documented Grade 2 thrombocytopenia, and the absence of FDA‑approved targeted agents for DIPG, what is the most appropriate next therapeutic option?

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old boy presented with progressive gait instability and cranial nerve VI palsy. MRI revealed a diffusely infiltrating pontine lesion measuring 2.8 cm in maximal diameter. Histologic examination after stereotactic biopsy confirmed a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) WHO grade IV. Molecular profiling demonstrated an H3 K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V activating mutation; BRAF V600E was wild‑type. 

Initial management consisted of focal conformal radiotherapy delivered to a total dose of 54 Gy in 30 fractions (1.8 Gy per fraction) over six weeks. After completing radiation, the patient enrolled in a phase II clinical trial evaluating oral ONC201 combined with the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The protocol stipulated ONC201 at 625 mg/m² administered once weekly and panobinostat at 20 mg/m² given orally three times weekly. The patient tolerated the regimen well for the first six weeks, during which repeat MRI showed a 30 % reduction in tumor volume. 

At week 7, laboratory monitoring revealed grade 3 thrombocytopenia (platelets 45 × 10⁹/L). Per the trial amendment, the ONC201 dose was reduced by 20 % while panobinostat was held. Consequently, the ONC201 dose was adjusted to 500 mg/m² weekly. 

Given persistent disease progression at week 12, the treating team initiated a second investigational protocol involving the PI3K/mTOR inhibitor paxalisib. Paxalisib was administered orally at 30 mg once daily without a loading dose. Because the patient had not harbored a BRAF V600E mutation, dabrafenib was not introduced. To augment the anti‑tumor effect, a focal re‑irradiation boost to the residual tumor was delivered: 24 Gy in 12 fractions (2 Gy per fraction) over two weeks, commencing two weeks after paxalisib initiation. 

In the combined cohort of patients receiving the ONC201/panobinostat regimen, the median overall survival was reported as 12 months, with a median progression‑free survival of 4 months. In contrast, the paxalisib monotherapy arm demonstrated a median overall survival of 9 months. The patient’s current performance status is Karnofsky 80 % and he continues on paxalisib with close hematologic monitoring.

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old girl presented with a 3‑month history of progressive gait instability, dysphagia, and new onset of diplopia. MRI of the brain showed a diffuse, infiltrative lesion centered in the pons, measuring 3.2 cm in greatest dimension, with characteristic T2 hyperintensity and mild contrast enhancement. She underwent a stereotactic biopsy, and molecular profiling revealed an H3‑K27M mutation (histone H3.3) and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V mutation; no BRAF V600E mutation was detected. Baseline laboratory studies were within normal limits except for a hemoglobin of 12.1 g/dL and platelet count of 210 ×10⁹/L. Her performance status was Karnofsky 80.

The patient received standard focal radiotherapy (54 Gy in 30 fractions over 6 weeks) without concurrent chemotherapy. Four weeks after completing radiation, she was enrolled in a phase II clinical trial evaluating the combination of panobinostat and ONC201. Panobinostat was administered orally at 20 mg/m² three times weekly (Monday, Wednesday, Friday), and ONC201 was given orally at 625 mg once weekly. She tolerated the regimen well, with the only notable adverse event being Grade 2 thrombocytopenia (platelet nadir 85 ×10⁹/L) that resolved without dose modification. Serial MRIs at 8‑ and 12‑week intervals demonstrated stable disease.

At the 4‑month assessment (approximately 16 weeks after trial initiation), repeat MRI revealed new, focal enhancing nodules within the pons and extension into the bilateral middle cerebellar peduncles, consistent with disease progression. The treating team discontinued the investigational regimen. Given the lack of FDA‑approved targeted therapies for H3‑K27M‑mutant diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma, the oncologist reviewed available options. Temozolomide is FDA‑approved for adult high‑grade glioma but has limited efficacy in pediatric DIPG and was previously considered unsuitable due to the patient’s prior radiation and modest hematologic reserve. A separate phase I/II trial investigating the EZH2 inhibitor tazemetostat (800 mg/m² twice daily) in H3‑K27M‑mutant pediatric gliomas is currently recruiting and permits enrollment of patients who have progressed after radiation and a prior investigational agent. No other active trials targeting ACVR1 mutations were available in the region.

The family wishes to pursue the most evidence‑based, mutation‑directed therapy while minimizing further hematologic toxicity.

ground_truth.context:
A 7‑year‑old boy presented with progressive gait instability and cranial nerve VI palsy. MRI revealed a diffusely infiltrating pontine lesion measuring 2.8 cm in maximal diameter. Histologic examination after stereotactic biopsy confirmed a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) WHO grade IV. Molecular profiling demonstrated an H3 K27M mutation and a concurrent ACVR1 G328V activating mutation; BRAF V600E was wild‑type. 

Initial management consisted of focal conformal radiotherapy delivered to a total dose of 54 Gy in 30 fractions (1.8 Gy per fraction) over six weeks. After completing radiation, the patient enrolled in a phase II clinical trial evaluating oral ONC201 combined with the histone deacetylase inhibitor panobinostat. The protocol stipulated ONC201 at 625 mg/m² administered once weekly and panobinostat at 20 mg/m² given orally three times weekly. The patient tolerated the regimen well for the first six weeks, during which repeat MRI showed a 30 % reduction in tumor volume. 

At week 7, laboratory monitoring revealed grade 3 thrombocytopenia (platelets 45 × 10⁹/L). Per the trial amendment, the ONC201 dose was reduced by 20 % while panobinostat was held. Consequently, the ONC201 dose was adjusted to 500 mg/m² weekly. 

Given persistent disease progression at week 12, the treating team initiated a second investigational protocol involving the PI3K/mTOR inhibitor paxalisib. Paxalisib was administered orally at 30 mg once daily without a loading dose. Because the patient had not harbored a BRAF V600E mutation, dabrafenib was not introduced. To augment the anti‑tumor effect, a focal re‑irradiation boost to the residual tumor was delivered: 24 Gy in 12 fractions (2 Gy per fraction) over two weeks, commencing two weeks after paxalisib initiation. 

In the combined cohort of patients receiving the ONC201/panobinostat regimen, the median overall survival was reported as 12 months, with a median progression‑free survival of 4 months. In contrast, the paxalisib monotherapy arm demonstrated a median overall survival of 9 months. The patient’s current performance status is Karnofsky 80 % and he continues on paxalisib with close hematologic monitoring.
